You have read about the statement that electricity is the flow of charge.Now there in lies your answer.You see the structure of a typical atom.A nucleus with elections rotating around it in external orbits. Now when you the electrodes create a strike or ignite the process.Then it's not the electron that start flowing, it's the charge or vibration.Carried from one atom to another with the help of valence electrons. They vibrate along their plane of rotation around the nucleus & the electron of the next atom receives this vibration from the former..& thus the electricity is formed.. & there is your vibration.

When an molecule reaches a thermally excited state it vibrates. This transfers the energy to the neighbouring molecule. In case of atoms, the electrons in the valence shell does the vibration , the energy of which is caught up by the valence electrons of the neighbouring atom, which itself starts to vibrate. And charge transfer takes place in the process..
